entry.title: Velociraptor‚Äôs new cousin is a raptor unlike any seen before
entry.summary: The newly named raptor Shri rapax was smuggled by poachers, rescued from the black market, and then, sometime following a CT-scan in 2016, its skull went missing. Shri rapax had bigger claws and potentially a stronger bite than its Hollywood relative. But paleontologists still don‚Äôt know the whereabouts of its head, which went missing. Sometime before 2010, in the red sands of Mongolia‚Äôs Gobi Desert brimming with fossils, poachers excavated and stole the exquisite skeleton of a carnivorous dinosaur. They smuggled the fossil out of the country and onto the black market. It passed through private collections in Japan and England and was eventually acquired by the French fossil company Eldonia. In 2016, one of the fossil‚Äôs owners had the dinosaur‚Äôs skull and four vertebrae‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 unusual outdoor events, from the offbeat to the awe-inspiring
entry.summary:
Celebrate Trails Day, hosted by The Great American Rail-Trail, encourages people to get outside and be active. Pond skimming, sprinting in heels‚Äîthese annual adventures range from death-defying to mundane.
We‚Äôve been hearing a lot in recent years about how awe is good for our mental and physical health. Finding awe in adventure can be as simple as watching others do something incredible or trying it ourselves. Research suggests a viral, contagious component to wondrous encounters, enhanced when we share them with others‚Äînot on social media, but as an actual experience.
Awe can be triggered by art, nature, people, or acts of mind-blowing skill or risk. Like from skiing down a snow-covered hill before skimming across a pond of cold water, or from watching a group of people in a ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What lymphatic drainage massage actually does for your body
entry.summary:
Lymphatic drainage massages have become a popular treatment for those looking to slim their face, but experts say the real benefits of lymphatic treatments are often misunderstood. ‚ÄúLymphfluencers‚Äù claim this type of massage can filter out toxins, help you lose weight, and boost your immune system. Here‚Äôs what science says.
From dry brushes to targeted massages, lymphatic drainage is prolific across social media. A single influencer‚Äôs video can accumulate over a million views with promises that massage techniques will eliminate waste or boost weight loss.
But lymphatic medicine is nothing new: Hippocrates observed and described lymph nodes in the fourth century B.C. The first known use of the term ‚Äúlymphatics‚Äù was in the 1600s in Denmark and Sweden, and medical scholars began ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How knitting may be rewiring your brain
entry.summary:
From knitting to woodwork, slow and steady hobbies may offer surprising brain benefits, including reduced stress and better long-term memory. ‚ÄúGrandma hobbies‚Äù like knitting are making a comeback among Gen Z‚Äîbut it‚Äôs not just for nostalgia. Neuroscience shows these tactile pastimes may help preserve brain health as we age.
The rhythmic click of needles. The softness of yarn running over fingertips. The satisfying logic of knit, purl, repeat. Knitting‚Äîand other so-called ‚Äúgrandma hobbies‚Äù‚Äîis making a comeback, especially among younger generations. According to Eventbrite data, Gen Z‚Äôs interest in ‚Äúgrannycore‚Äù gatherings, such as knitting circles and needlework workshops, has surged in recent months, driven in part by a search for relief from digital burnout.
But the benefits go‚Ä¶

entry.title: Whales are going eerily silent. Experts say it‚Äôs a warning sign.
entry.summary:
A blue whale swims near the coast of Sri Lanka. Studies from California to New Zealand have shown that certain whale species, such as blue whales, stop singing when heat waves disrupt their food sources. A six-year study off California‚Äôs coast shows how marine heat waves and noise pollution are silencing the ocean‚Äôs largest singers. Does saving the ocean start with hearing it?
Beneath the ocean's surface, a symphony ripples and rolls, ricochets and hums‚Äîand whales pour their songs into the deep soundscape like streams of molten silver.
Deep within the noise, a 32-mile-long cable stretches out from the California coastline along the seafloor, tethered to the ground 3,000 feet below the surface. At its end is a two-inch-wide metal cylinder standing on three legs. This hydrophone‚Ä¶

entry.title: Deputy UN chief urges bold action to transform food systems at global summit in Addis Ababa
entry.summary: United Nations Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed on Tuesday called on countries to double down on efforts to transform food systems, describing them as ‚Äúone of the greatest solutions‚Äù to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres has expressed sadness over the passing of Dr. David Nabarro, who played a leading role in the Organization‚Äôs efforts to respond to challenges such as hunger, Ebola and the COVID-19 pandemic.

entry.title: UN peacekeeping can work in a fractured world ‚Äì if there is political will
entry.summary: In an era marked by geopolitical fragmentation and rising global tensions, United Nations peace operations face unprecedented challenges ‚Äì but senior officials told the Security Council on Tuesday that with renewed political will and strategic adaptation, these missions remain indispensable tools for conflict resolution and protection of civilians worldwide.

entry.title: Russian attack on Ukrainian prison kills 16: UN rights monitors
entry.summary: An attack on a prison in the south-eastern Zaporizhzhia region of Ukraine on Monday reportedly left 16 prisoners dead and almost 100 injured, violating international law, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) has said.

entry.title: LIVE COVERAGE: Day 2 of high-level conference on two-State solution for Israel and Palestine
entry.summary: Welcome to our continuing live coverage of the high-level international conference at UN Headquarters, aimed at advancing practical steps toward achieving a two-State solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict. Mandated by the General Assembly, the three-day meeting features plenaries, working groups and interventions from senior UN officials and Member States. UN News app users can follow here.

entry.title: Who were the Moors?
entry.summary:
If the term ‚ÄúMoor‚Äù seems familiar but confusing, there‚Äôs a reason. Though it can be found throughout literature, art, and history books, it does not actually describe a specific ethnicity or race.
Instead, the concept of Moors has been used to describe alternatively the reign of Muslims in Spain, Europeans of African descent, and others for centuries.
Derived from the Latin word ‚ÄúMaurus,‚Äù the term was originally used to describe Berbers and ethnic groups from the ancient Roman province of Mauretania in what is now North Africa.
Over time, it was increasingly applied to the Muslim population living in Europe. Beginning in the Renaissance, ‚ÄúMoor‚Äù and ‚Äúblackamoor‚Äù were also used to describe any person with dark skin.
In A.D. 711, a group of North African Muslims led by t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Are orange cats really the goofiest? Genetics may have an answer.
entry.summary:
Orange cats are said to have goofy personalities. Is that really true? The best science on ginger feline behavior hints, yeah, there might be something special about them.
Hanging from lamps, catapulting off countertops, tackling the dog, biting your legs unexpectedly‚Äîthere are many wacky behaviors associated with orange cats, often captured on TikTok, whose owners swear are extra derpy, slapdash, and yet also friendly to a fault.
But scientifically speaking, are orange cats actually any different than cats of other colors?
For starters, orange cats are not a breed, like British shorthair or Siamese. Cats of many breeds, from Maine coons and munchkins to American bobtails and Siberians, can have orange colorations. Which perhaps makes it all the weirder that orange cat a‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 bullet train journeys across China
entry.summary:
China's high-speed bullet trains are a great way to explore different areas of the country. With the world‚Äôs longest high-speed rail network and a new record-breaking bullet train, China is reshaping how travelers explore this vast nation.
On a clear Beijing morning, I settle into my seat on board the G87 bullet train. Bound for Chengdu, we‚Äôll make the nearly 1,200-mile journey‚Äîabout the distance from New York City to Kansas City‚Äîin just 7.5 hours. Through the window, buildings blur as we quietly pick up speed and soon we‚Äôre sailing across the Yellow River, past Xi‚Äôan‚Äôs ancient walls, and into the mountains of Sichuan.
China is blazing a new future with its rail network, which includes more than 28,500 miles of high-speed tracks (for comparison, Europe‚Äôs is around 7,450 miles)‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who was Nostradamus‚Äîand why do his prophecies rile us up?
entry.summary:
What‚Äôs in the future‚Ä¶and how does the world end?¬†They‚Äôre tempting questions‚Äîand one that, centuries ago, doctor and self-styled prophet Nostradamus always claimed to answer. His famed predictions range from confusing to creepy, and his acolytes believe his 16th-century predictions still ring true today. His¬†supposed 2025 prophecies include long wars, plague, and a fireball that may destroy Earth.
In fact, Nostradamus is so well known for his predictions that a 1672¬†reference¬†to him is among the first documented uses of the word ‚Äúprognostication‚Äù in the English language.¬†
But the man some think of as a prophet was no divine being. He was a real-life French physician, apothecary, and author whose bold predictions earned him a name in the tumult of Renaissance Europe. Here‚Äôs what to‚Ä¶

entry.title: Female invasive joro spiders may dabble in cannibalism
entry.summary: Invasive joro spiders have been building their enormous, golden webs across the eastern United States since 2014. Sometimes the webs stand alone, but other times 10 or 15 females dwell in a mosaic of interconnected webs stretching all the way up a tree‚Äîan arachnid apartment complex of sorts. New research finds that these stereotypically tolerant spiders can engage in unneighborly behavior, attacking and even cannibalizing each other. undefinedTo study female joro spider fighting in the field, researchers placed pairs on the same web. Just one pair fought. Joro spiders are native to east Asia. Females look like a yellow and black grape with toothpicks sticking out of it‚Äîbig enough to fill the palm of a hand, says Andy Davis, an ecologist at the University of Georgia in Athens. ‚ÄúFo‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Parisian chef is fighting for feminism from the kitchen
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Manon Fleury approaches being a chef the same way she does fencing. ‚ÄúGastronomy is often presented as a job in which you compete against others ‚Äî but in reality, it‚Äôs not at all,‚Äù says Fleury, who, prior to opening her Paris restaurant Datil, was a member of the French fencing team. Demanding schedules, adrenaline and the ultimate satisfaction that comes with success can be found in both disciplines. But it‚Äôs teamwork that‚Äôs important above all else. ‚ÄúWhat I advocate for at Datil is helping one another, kindness and respect ‚Äî values that can also be found in sports ‚Äî¬†while going above and beyond, a requirement in upscale gastronomy.‚Äù
Building a healthy work environment was one of the main concerns when Datil opened‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 of the most beautiful train stations in the U.S.
How Charles Lindbergh almost convinced Europe to cave to Hitler
entry.summary:
Charles Lindbergh standing in front of his plane, the Spirit of St. Louis, which he used on his transatlantic flight. The aviator was so impressed by German propaganda that he grossly overestimated Hitler‚Äôs airpower.
I have to declare a personal stake that shapes my opinion as I write this story. It has its origins in 1940, 85 years ago this month. I was seven years old, living near London. I watched the choreography of a great battle underway, etched in vapor trails high above in the crisp blue sky of summer, the combat that became known as the Battle of Britain. I wasn‚Äôt scared. I watched with the detached excitement of a child unaware of how perilous those days were for us. That understanding would come later, from my work as a journalist, spending years discovering how closely ‚Ä¶

entry.title: World News in Brief: Cambodia-Thailand ceasefire, bloody weekend in Ukraine, stop hepatitis deaths
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres has welcomed the ceasefire agreement between Cambodia and Thailand following days of deadly fighting over their mutual border.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: UN sounds the alarm as health and food crises worsen across the country
entry.summary: The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) is alarmed by escalating health and food crises across Sudan, notably as cholera cases continue to rise in the locality of Tawila, North Darfur state.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Slight decrease in global hunger as inequalities widen, UN report reveals
entry.summary: An interagency group from the UN released the flagship¬†2025 State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World (SOFI) report on Monday, estimating a global, yet uneven, decline in hunger since 2022.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Fragile ceasefire in Sweida ‚Äòlargely holding‚Äô amid volatility
entry.summary: A fragile de-escalation in Syria‚Äôs Sweida region is ‚Äúlargely holding‚Äù after weeks of violence displaced 175,000 people, killed hundreds and devastated critical infrastructure ‚Äì exposing deep fissures in the country‚Äôs political transition.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN condemns deadly attack on worshippers in DR Congo
entry.summary: The UN peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, MONUSCO, strongly condemned an attack by the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) on civilians during the night of 26 to 27 July.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres: ‚ÄòBreaking point‚Äô reached in Israel-Palestine conflict, urgent action needed on two-State solution
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres has warned that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has reached a breaking point, calling for bold political action to salvage the two-State solution and halt what he described as the systemic dismantling of peace efforts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE COVERAGE: High-level conference on two-State solution for Israel and Palestine
entry.summary: Welcome to our live coverage of the high-level international conference at UN Headquarters, aimed at advancing practical steps toward achieving a two-State solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict. Mandated by the General Assembly, the three-day meeting features plenaries, working groups and interventions from senior UN officials and Member States. UN News App users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: While Gaza ceasefire remains elusive, UN readies for Conference around Israel-Palestine two-State solution
entry.summary: A world in which a sovereign State of Palestine and Israel co-exist peacefully seems a distant prospect, particularly in light of the 7 October 2023 attacks by Hamas on Israel, and the subsequent Israeli bombardment of Gaza. A high-level UN conference opening on 28 July will, nevertheless, serve as the latest UN-backed attempt to find a way to end the conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Amid starvation in Gaza, Sudan, Guterres slams hunger ‚Äòas a weapon of war‚Äô
entry.summary: As starvation worsens in war-torn Gaza, UN agencies repeated warnings on Monday that Israel‚Äôs decision to support a ‚Äúone-week scale-up‚Äù of aid is far from enough to reverse deadly malnutrition rates in the enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Trace the backcountry trails of Banff on horseback
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the side paddock, a team of mules jostles, their heads low, long ears twitching as they snort and stamp impatiently. The beasts ‚Äî horse-donkey hybrids ‚Äî are being loaded up with gear for our expedition into Banff National Park, western Canada, saddle bags of supplies ballooning at their sides. Fuel, food, grain, linen and the inevitable bottle of whisky: it‚Äôs a packing list untouched by time.
As the string of mules ambles past in a tethered line, hooves kicking up lazy clouds of dust, it feels like a scene from a Wild West flick, shot in glorious Technicolor against the swaggering backdrop of the Canadian Rockies. But a sidelong glance at the stable yard spins a different yarn, as the present-day wranglers graft‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Alabama‚Äôs emerging wine country should be your next road trip
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Given its southerly latitude, it may seem surprising that Alabama is home to a burgeoning wine country. But amid the undulating landscape piercing the state‚Äôs northern half, you‚Äôll find a colourful, characterful wine trail surrounded by some truly beautiful, waterfall-studded scenery. While southern Alabama is as flat as an American pancake, the sylvan foothills of the Appalachian Mountains enter from the northeast of the state and their dense, layered foliage make driving through this corner of ‚ÄòDixie‚Äô a joy.¬†
But don‚Äôt expect grand, urbane wineries on the scale of Napa or Sonoma. For the most part, Alabama‚Äôs handful of vineyards are helmed by delightfully small mom-and-pop operations offering warm, avuncular welc‚Ä¶

entry.title: Look to Austria for wines to try this summer
entry.summary:
Wherever you go in the country, it's hard to overstate Austrians' passion for wine. Known for its aromatic whites, Austria also has outstanding sweet wines, reds and field blends, all best enjoyed in a rural tavern.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
I first came across Austrian wine around 30 years ago in San Francisco, of all places, at a restaurant called The Slanted Door that served Vietnamese food, with which I was equally unfamiliar. I was blown away by a fresh, peppery white called gr√ºner veltliner ‚Äî a wine made from a grape of the same name ‚Äî along with how well it suited the dishes we‚Äôd ordered.
Since then, it‚Äôs become hugely popular. Almost every supermarket has an own-label gr√ºner and it‚Äôs still my go-to with most Southeast Asia‚Ä¶

entry.title: The science behind why Black Sabbath‚Äôs music sounded ‚Äòsatanic‚Äô
entry.summary:
The idea that two simple notes‚Äînot a song, just tones‚Äîcould be ‚Äúbanned‚Äú may seem ludicrous. But that‚Äôs the legend behind the crushing opening riff of Black Sabbath‚Äôs 1970 debut. With just three ominous notes, guitarist Tony Iommi, alongside the anguished vocals of the late Ozzy Osbourne, unleashed a sound so unsettling it was said to have been forbidden for centuries.‚ÄúThose notes were banned many years ago,‚Äù Iommi told the BBC in 2014. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs supposed to have been a satanic thing.‚Äù
While rock legend has never been the most reliable (see: Ozzy and the bat), this one does have a whisper of truth. Black Sabbath recruited what music theorists refer to as the ‚Äòtritone,‚Äô ‚Äîa dissonant interval once avoided by medieval choirs and now known in music lore as the ‚Äúdevil‚Äôs interval.‚Äù Also referred‚Ä¶

entry.title: Pollution, melting microbes, undamming rivers, risks for elders: 4 key climate issues
entry.summary: In a world increasingly shaped by climate extremes, environmental experts are delivering a blunt warning: four rapidly emerging threats could reshape life for millions unless urgent action is taken.

entry.title: Who were the Neanderthals‚Äîand why did they go extinct?
entry.summary:
This reconstruction of a female Neanderthal was made using ancient DNA evidence. Our ancient ancestors looked similar to modern humans but with more prominent brows and big teeth and eyes. Scientists believe they were also smarter than originally believed. Neanderthals were a hardy species, but these ancient human relatives disappeared 40,000 years ago. Here‚Äôs what scientists know.

  Neanderthals were our closest known relatives and walked the Earth between at least 400,000 and 40,000 years ago. But since their fossilized bones were discovered more than 160 years ago, there are still many questions about what they were like. The bones were uncovered by limestone quarry workers digging in Germany‚Äôs Neander Valley in 1856. At first, they thought they‚Äôd uncovered the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The picturesque Spanish villages that tourists haven't found‚Äîyet
entry.summary:
Slightly up north of Madrid and Barcelona, nestling at the foothills of the Pyrenees, lies the region of Aragon, rich in history and natural beauty. Here, green hills hug the soaring mountains and dense forests open up to flowering meadows. Down in the valleys, ancient castles hide among the olive groves, endless vineyards disappear into the horizon and centuries-old villages bask in the Mediterranean sun all summer long.
Aragon‚Äôs historical claim to fame reaches all the way to America. Known as the Kingdom of Aragon in the 11th century, it became a precursor to the modern-day Spain, when King Ferdinand of Aragon married Queen Isabella of Castile in 1469. About two decades later, the royal couple financed Christopher Columbus‚Äôs voyage to the New World.¬†
In recent years, beautiful‚Ä¶

entry.title: The UK's nightlife has lost its mojo‚Äîcan it be saved?
entry.summary:
With tickets to club nights costing up to ¬£50 and pints averaging over ¬£5, many can't afford to go out any more. Venues are in crisis, with more closures than ever ‚Äî but superclubs, sober parties and new government powers could save the after-dark music scene.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Nights out have been a staple of British life since the early 20th century, when the country‚Äôs first nightclubs opened. But in recent years, the country has seen a surge in venue closures, with a study by the Night Time Industries Association (NTIA) suggesting that there could be no nightclubs by 2030. With a clutch of big openings and a new government taskforce, there are reasons to remain hopeful ‚Äî but are we witnessing the end of nightlife as we know i‚Ä¶

entry.title: 20 years after Katrina, New Orleanians are redefining 'home'
entry.summary:
Shelton Alexander is one of hundred of thousands of New Orleans residents who survived the devastation of Hurricane Katrina in 2005. After one of the deadliest hurricanes in American history, many New Orleans residents faced a mountain of obstacles to rebuild. These are their stories.
On August 28, 2005, the eve of Hurricane Katrina‚Äôs landfall, Shelton Alexander stood outside his home in St. Bernard Parish, a neighborhood in New Orleans, as a storm warning echoed from a nearby radio. Katrina was gaining strength by the hour.
At that point, the poet and former Marine made sure his mother evacuated. But for himself, staying felt like the only option‚Äîa mix of necessity, responsibility, and quiet defiance in the face of a storm he knew would be unlike anything he‚Äôd seen before. ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What was it like to live in Old Babylon?
entry.summary:
The city of Babylon, flanking the Euphrates River in Lower Mesopotamia, reached the zenith of its early age during the reign of King Hammurabi (r.1792-1750 B.C.). Under his rule, the capital of the Babylonian empire was consolidated as a cosmopolitan hub, attracting migrants from across the region. The Empire as a whole had been gaining power and prestige during the Old Babylonian Empire (1894‚Äì1595 B.C.), but Hammurabi went on to take over large swaths of territory in Mesopotamia, conquering far flung cities such as Ur, Eshnunna, Assur, Nineveh, and Tuttul. As Hammurabi‚Äôs reach extended, much of the kingdom flourished‚Äîculturally, economically, socially, and in religion‚Äî especially in the capital, Babylon.
The thousands of cuneiform texts that survive from this time provide fasci‚Ä¶

entry.title: How one shipwreck and a cargo of lost gold sparked a U.S. financial panic
entry.summary: When the Central America sank, it became the worst maritime disaster in America‚Äôs history. The loss of the gold shipment in the hold contributed to a nationwide economic crisis. The S.S. Central America sank off the coast of South Carolina in 1857, taking with it 425 lives and a fortune in gold rush bounty. As the sun slipped below the horizon on the evening of September 8, 1857, a festive atmosphere prevailed in the first-class dining room aboard the S.S. Central America. The side-wheel paddle steamer had left Havana that morning under fair skies and was making its way to New York City on the second and final leg of a voyage that had begun five days earlier in Panama. Aboard were 477 passengers and a crew of 101. Seated at the captain‚Äôs table that night was a newly‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 of the best book festivals around the world
entry.summary:
A woman poses for a photo at the Calabash International Literary Festival in Treasure Beach, Jamaica. The family-owned Jake‚Äôs Hotel hosts the annual festival. From Jamaica to Jaipur, these literary festivals celebrate the power of the written word and offer you a chance to hear from celebrated and up-and-coming authors‚Äîas well as fellow bibliophiles.
The ritual of convening around books is a worldwide tradition‚Äîfrom the small fishing village of Treasure Beach in Jamaica to a countryside street in Wales. To pore over a new book in a new setting with like-minded people garners community and inspiration. Add in a gorgeous setting, riveting speakers, and some of the world‚Äôs best restaurants and hotels nearby, and book festivals can serve as a starting point for a greater travel adventu‚Ä¶

entry.title: Cosmic radiation gave the Fantastic Four superpowers. Here's what would happen in real life.
entry.summary:
When we gaze up at the night sky, we often marvel at the twinkling stars, distant planets, and expansive galaxies. Yet, beyond the visible spectrum lies a more mysterious aspect of the cosmos‚Äîcosmic radiation.
These are high energy particles that stream through the universe at nearly the speed of light, according to Dimitra Atri of the Mars Research Group at New York University Abu Dhabi's Center for Astrophysics and Space Science. They originate from events like supernova explosions and solar flares and travel through space, constantly bombarding Earth in all directions and entering its atmosphere.
(How cosmic rays helped find a tunnel in Egypt's Great Pyramid.)
In Marvel Studios‚Äô The Fantastic Four: First Steps, now playing only in theaters, the Fantastic 4 receive their p‚Ä¶

entry.title: The women in Carl Jung‚Äôs shadow
entry.summary:
For two generations, Emma Jung‚Äîthe wife of the famous Swiss psychoanalyst Carl Jung‚Äîwas remembered inside her family mostly as a beloved mother and grandmother. Her original work documenting the deep and rigorous exploration of her own unconscious simply wasn‚Äôt discussed.
‚ÄúNo one was any longer aware of what she actually produced,‚Äù says Thomas Fischer, great-grandson of Carl and Emma‚Äîand the former director of the Foundation of the Works of C.G. Jung‚Äîwho currently serves as a board member and the editor for the foundation.
Now, 150 years after Carl Jung‚Äôs birth, Emma and several of his other female collaborators are finally stepping into the spotlight and being recognized as brilliant thinkers of their own who helped shape some of Jung‚Äôs most famous theories, including individuat‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN urges restraint as Thailand-Cambodia clashes displace thousands; Security Council meets
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has urged ‚Äúutmost restraint‚Äù amid intensifying border clashes between Thailand and Cambodia as the Security Council met behind closed doors on Friday to address the most serious escalation between the two Southeast Asian neighbours in more than a decade.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Deadly sectarian violence displaces thousands in Sweida; healthcare attacked
entry.summary: As deadly sectarian violence continues to displace hundreds of thousands of civilians in Syria‚Äôs Sweida Governorate, the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed on Friday that attacks on health facilities had killed two doctors.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: More deaths reported as starvation spreads
entry.summary: The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has again sounded the alarm over the catastrophic and rapidly deteriorating conditions in the Gaza Strip as Israeli military operations continue to cause death, displacement and destruction.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza First Person: ‚ÄòThe best of humankind in a place abandoned by humanity‚Äô
entry.summary: In the centre of war-torn Gaza, UN staff continue to work despite the ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù destruction and suffering around them, according to the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) Head of Office.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN warns of escalating human toll in Ukraine amid relentless aerial attacks, mounting aid shortfall
entry.summary: Russian aerial attacks continue to intensify across Ukraine, exacting a rising toll on civilians and infrastructure, senior UN officials told the Security Council on Friday, warning of mounting humanitarian needs amid faltering donor support.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: In hard-hitting human rights address, Guterres calls for urgent action on Gaza, authoritarianism and climate justice
entry.summary: The world is facing a ‚Äúmoral crisis‚Äù marked by rising authoritarianism, deepening inequality and a dangerous indifference to human suffering, UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres warns in a powerful address on human rights.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 1.3 million Sudanese return home, offering fragile hope for recovery
entry.summary: With pockets of relative safety emerging in Sudan, over 1.3 million Sudanese people, including one million who were internally displaced and over 300,000 refugees, have returned home, according to UN agencies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Situation in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN Security Council is meeting on Friday morning to discuss the situation in Ukraine amid mounting concerns over the intensifying hostilities and growing humanitarian needs. Senior UN political affairs and humanitarian officials are expected to brief the Council. Follow our live coverage from UN News, in coordination with UN Meetings Coverage, for updates from the chamber. UN News App users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Women and girls of African descent: Celebrating contributions, recognising challenges
entry.summary: This Friday marks the first observation of the International Day of Women and Girls of African Descent, following a declaration last year by the UN General Assembly.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Forest bathing is the secret to feel-good travel
entry.summary:
Bluebells bloom across a small forest in Shaftesbury, Dorset, United Kingdom. Studies show that forest bathing in woodlands such as this can boost physical and mental health. These five destinations maximize the health benefits of the Japanese art of forest bathing.
Forest bathing emerged in Japan in the 1980s as a physiological and psychological exercise called shinrin-yoku, meaning ‚Äúforest bathing‚Äù or ‚Äútaking in the forest atmosphere.‚Äù Now this type of walking is a fitness trend and a mindfulness practice for better mental health.
The original purpose was two-fold: to offer an antidote to tech-boom burnout and inspire people to reconnect with and protect the country‚Äôs forests.
The Japanese quickly embraced this form of ‚Äúecotherapy.‚Äù In the 1990s, researchers began study‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why you should visit these 5 European lakes
entry.summary:
These five European lakes are worthy of your attention this summer. From tri-country bike rides around Germany‚Äôs Lake Constance to swims in the shadow of towering mountains in Slovenia‚Äôs Lake Bohinj, Europe‚Äôs lakes are so lovely in summer that you won‚Äôt miss the sea for a minute. Packing in history, culture, food, beaches, alley-woven villages and big wilderness, here are five favourites to get you started.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As the summer heat rises along the coast of the Med, turn your gaze instead to Europe‚Äôs dazzlingly diverse array of lakes. Beyond swimming, kayaking and standup paddleboarding in crystal-clear waters, there‚Äôs plenty to explore ‚Äî think medieval castles and vineyards, prehistoric pile dwellings and Byzantine m‚Ä¶

entry.title: Will psychedelics ever live up to their hype?
Are we alone? Earth‚Äôs giant new telescope could finally tell us.
How Louis Braille revolutionized a writing system
entry.summary:
Where would we be without writing? From its origins over 5,000 years ago in ancient Mesopotamia, the history of writing echoes the history of humanity. The Greeks and Romans developed unique alphabets, the Chinese evolved complex characters, and today we read novels, newspapers, and social media. A bedrock of human civilization, writing is fundamental for the rule of law and the accumulation of knowledge and culture. Yet it was not until the 19th century that blind people had access to writing.
Between 1824 and 1825, Louis Braille created a system of raised dot letters that could be read with the hands. Initially ignored, his invention would be universally adopted by the 20th century, opening a new world of learning for the visually impaired. In a speech at the Sorbonne on the centenn‚Ä¶

entry.title: This city offers a stunning respite from Venice‚Äôs crowds
entry.summary:
About 40 miles from Venice‚Äôs winding waterways and busy plazas lies Vicenza, an elegant Renaissance jewel. To visit Vicenza is to breathe in the genius of one of history‚Äôs most influential architects, Andrea Palladio.
Though born in nearby Padua, this 16th century architect made his study of classical Greek and Roman architecture central to the design style that later reached throughout Europe and across the Atlantic‚Äîa style that inspired Thomas Jefferson to design Monticello after Palladian ideals.
Come for the architecture, but stay to explore a rich tapestry of history and gastronomy. From its museums full of fine art to its stately villas, Vicenza is worth the day trip from Veneto‚Äôs more crowded destinations. ¬†¬†
Piazza dei Signori is a beautiful starting point. It‚Äôs he‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is it possible to take too much melatonin?
entry.summary:
If you‚Äôve ever taken a melatonin supplement as a last-ditch attempt to save your sleep, you‚Äôre in good company: Research suggests people in the U.S. have steadily reached for more melatonin over the past couple of decades, and an American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) survey estimates that roughly two-thirds of U.S. adults have used some form of melatonin to help them drift off.¬†
The appeal is undeniable: Your brain naturally makes this hormone to regulate your sleep-wake cycle. The synthetic form of melatonin usually found in supplements is a relatively low-risk substance for adults, plus it‚Äôs available over the counter. Package this into a trendy bottle brimming with colorful gummies (with plenty of endorsements from ‚Äúwellness‚Äù influencers), and you‚Äôre giving the chronically exha‚Ä¶

entry.title: Two ex-militia leaders in Central African Republic sentenced for war crimes, crimes against humanity
entry.summary: Two former leaders of the predominantly Christian Anti-Balaka militia in the Central African Republic have been convicted of multiple war crimes and crimes against humanity by the International Criminal Court (ICC).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Thailand-Cambodia border hostilities, humanitarian efforts in Syria and attacks across Ukraine
entry.summary: In a dramatic escalation of a long-standing border dispute, a deadly exchange of fire between Thailand and Cambodia killed at least 11 civilians and a soldier on Thursday, according to news reports. Both states are claiming the other side fired first.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòThe UN is here to do the right things‚Äô: Envoy Colin Stewart bids farewell but keeps the faith
entry.summary: After nearly three decades on the frontlines of UN‚Äôs peace operations ‚Äì from Timor-Leste‚Äôs turbulent independence referendum to Western Sahara‚Äôs protracted ceasefire and Cyprus‚Äô frozen conflict ‚Äì Colin Stewart is leaving the Organization with his faith in it intact.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN forum affirms stronger commitment to achieve sustainable development
entry.summary: The High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF) has concluded at United Nations Headquarters in New York following a week-and-a-half of substantive discussion between Member States, civil society representatives and UN agencies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòFamine silently begins to unfold‚Äô in Gaza, UNRWA chief says
entry.summary: ‚ÄúPeople in Gaza are neither dead nor alive, they are walking corpses.‚Äù

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global collaboration grows to address crises in Gaza, Sudan, Afghanistan
entry.summary: Amid growing geopolitical turbulence, the United Nations is deepening its collaboration with the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) to help address some of the world‚Äôs most complex and protracted conflicts, from Gaza and Sudan to Myanmar and Afghanistan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Torture, threats and arbitrary arrests: UN warns of ‚Äòserious abuses‚Äô against Afghans forced to return
entry.summary: Afghans returning to their country face ‚Äúserious violations‚Äù of their human rights committed by the Taliban de facto authorities, according to a United Nations report published on Thursday amid mass deportation campaigns from Iran and Pakistan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Deep-sea must not turn into ‚ÄòWild West‚Äô of rare minerals exploitation, agency head says
entry.summary: Nations are pursuing underwater exploration for highly sought-after rare earth minerals, but the head of the UN‚Äôs International Seabed Authority (ISA) said the deep-sea belongs to no single country or corporation as efforts are underway to ensure this rich resource will not become ‚Äúthe Wild West‚Äù of exploitation.

entry.title: Tips on Running a Successful Local Investigative Outlet
entry.summary: Despite starting out as an online newsletter with no office and no team, Joshi Herrmann‚Äôs Mill Media has grown into a case study on how to make big-impact local investigative journalism work.

entry.title: Who was Mary Magdalene?
entry.summary:
Mary Magdalene is one of the most recognized figures in the Bible. She has been called a woman possessed by demons, a sex worker, and the wife of Jesus.
Her story has been written and rewritten countless times in the 2,000 years since she was a follower of Jesus of Nazareth, yet so much about Mary Magdalene remains shrouded in mystery. She is sometimes confused with Mary of Bethany, another biblical figure, and thought to have written a Gospel. There are questions about her real name, when and where she was born, and how Mary Magdalene died.
What is true about her‚Äîand what archaeological evidence do scholars have about her life and world?
Textual evidence about Mary Magdalene largely comes from the canonical Gospels credited to Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. They identify ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Forget about 10,000 steps a day‚Äîscience now has a more accurate number
entry.summary:
An explorer walks across sand dunes on Socotra, Yemen, 2018. Getting 10,000 steps in every day can be challenging, and a new study suggests 7,000 steps can reduce the risk of developing common but serious health conditions. Walking more is associated with reduced risk for dementia, diabetes, heart disease, and more‚Äîbut a new study says you can get fewer than 10,000 steps a day and still see all those benefits.
If you‚Äôve been told that walking 10,000 steps a day is mandatory for good health, you might be surprised to learn that scientists suspect the figure was created to market pedometers and wasn't based on actual data. The number of steps that stave off numerous chronic conditions is actually much lower, according to a paper published today in Lancet Public Health that reviewed t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Different dino species traveled together‚Äîlike the movies
entry.summary:
A herd of ceratopsians (Styracosaurus albertensis) accompanied by an ankylosaur (Euplocephalus tutus) walk through an old river channel under the watchful eyes of two tyrannosaurs (Gorgosaurus libratus). A newly discovered trove of fossilized footprints provides what may be the first evidence of prehistoric diversity in dinosaur herds, though not everyone is convinced.
Across the African savanna, zebras and wildebeests travel together in massive herds often peppered with impalas and gazelles. The larger the herd, the safer its members are from predators like lions, hyenas and African wild dogs.
Scientists have wondered whether dinosaurs similarly engaged in mixed-species herding behavior. Children‚Äôs movies like ‚ÄúThe Land Before Time‚Äù series and ‚ÄúDinosaur‚Äù (2000) often depict m‚Ä¶

On its back, an overlapping fan of stiff structures likely caught the light, vibrant with color. They looked very much like feathers, but were something entirely different as the reptile wasn‚Äôt related to birds or dinosaurs, and it existed a hundred million years before the first dinosaur took wing.¬† Researchers have long believed things like‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Pew Research Center Uses Its National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS)
entry.summary: In 2020, Pew Research Center launched a new project called the National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS). NPORS is an annual, cross-sectional survey of U.S. adults. Respondents can answer either by paper or online, and they are selected using address-based sampling from the United States Postal Service‚Äôs computerized delivery sequence file. The post How Pew Research Center Uses Its National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS) appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 10 historic‚Äîand sometimes haunted‚Äîhotels in Colorado
entry.summary:
The Brown Palace Hotel was the passion project of Henry Brown, the real estate developer who donated land to create Denver's state capitol building. Ghost stories, swinging saloon doors, and old-world glamour‚Äîthese hotels offer more character than your average accommodation.
Colorado may be a beloved outdoor recreation destination, but it has more to offer than ski slopes and hiking trails. Once home to miners and cowboys, the Centennial State was a key player not only in the development of the American West but also in establishing Wild West culture. Whether deep in the Rocky Mountains or amid the urban sprawl of Denver, stay in historical hotels to experience this culture for yourself. These properties function as living museums, with antiques, ghosts, and Victorian architecture ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Childbirth is still too dangerous. This ancient profession can help.
entry.summary:
A midwife holds a newborn in Tzajalch√©n, Mexico, 2021. Midwives are making a big comeback, and solving a crisis in maternal health care.
It‚Äôs 5 a.m. at Mother Health International (MHI), a birth center in Northern Uganda affiliated with Yale University, when the call comes in from a local midwife about 12 miles away. A woman in her village has gone into labor. The alert sets a series of gears into motion: a motorcycle driver is immediately dispatched to zip down the mostly unpaved roads to her location, while the nurse midwives at MHI prepare a room for labor and delivery. Within an hour, the laboring mother and her local midwife arrive at MHI where she‚Äôs greeted by nurse midwives who work together to ensure a safe delivery. An ambulance stands ready in case the birth becomes diff‚Ä¶

entry.title: This one-minute workout could transform your health
entry.summary:
Social media hypes sprinting as a quick fix‚Äîbut research shows short bursts of high-intensity running can improve VO‚ÇÇ max, preserve fast-twitch muscle fibers, and support brain and bone health with minimal time investment. Influencers call sprinting the ultimate fat-burning workout. Experts say it‚Äôs more nuanced‚Äîbut research shows this high-intensity exercise offers surprising benefits for the heart, muscles, and even the brain.
Sprinting has been getting a lot of hype online. But the research backs it up: short, intense bursts of running offer powerful benefits‚Äîfrom cardiovascular fitness to strength and cognitive function. And you don‚Äôt have to do it every day to see results.
Because it‚Äôs high-impact, sprinting isn‚Äôt right for everyone. But for those without physical limitat‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 state parks that deliver the awe without the crowds
entry.summary:
Under the Milky Way Galaxy, a night explorer stands at the entrance to Moon Caves in Nevada's Cathedral Gorge State Park. Less famous but just as unforgettable, these state parks showcase iconic landscapes without the long lines at America‚Äôs national parks.
As popular national parks grapple with¬†another record-breaking year¬†of crowds, state-managed public lands offer a less-explored option. While a few parks, like Niagara Falls, with 9 million annual visitors, still contend with crowds, most feel almost deserted. If long lines and packed parking lots have you rethinking your travel plans to some of the busiest national parks, consider one of these eight state park alternatives that deliver the awe without the crowds.¬†
With prolific biodiversity within just a day‚Äôs drive of o‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòCorn sweat‚Äô‚Äîand other weird weather phenomena‚Äîexplained
entry.summary:
On a hot day, fields of corn transpiring water, also known as "corn sweat", can raise local humidity levels by 30 to 40 percent. The Midwest‚Äôs massive corn fields are making the region more humid as it battles a sweltering heatwave.
As the U.S. Midwest swelters under the effects of yet another heatwave, temperatures and humidity in the region are being further fueled by ‚Äúsweating‚Äù corn. If you didn‚Äôt have sweaty produce on your 2025 bingo card, you‚Äôre not alone; but ‚Äúcorn sweat‚Äù is a real phenomenon, well known to meteorologists and farmers alike, that adds moisture to the atmosphere and makes hot conditions even hotter and more unpleasant.
It‚Äôs just one unexpected way in which human activities, from agriculture to deforestation and pollution, can have surprising effects on r‚Ä¶

entry.title: Syria: Second convoy brings critical aid to Sweida

entry.title: Haiti: Violence and displacement driving humanitarian crisis as funding needs go unmet
entry.summary: Escalating gang violence and displacement continue to drive humanitarian needs in Haiti, the UN said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Nigeria: Amid record hunger and surging insecurity, emergency food assistance to stall entirely
entry.summary: At a time of escalating violence and record levels of hunger in Nigeria, critical funding shortfalls are forcing the UN World Food Program (WFP) to suspend all emergency food and nutrition aid for 1.3 million people in the northeast of the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Home is where the heart is ‚Äî and where development begins
entry.summary: When Denis Jobin, a senior evaluation specialist at the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), visited a slum in Kenya in March as part of an ongoing evaluation, the smell was overwhelming.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Court says countries are legally obligated to curb emissions, protect climate
entry.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) in the Hague, Netherlands, issued its advisory opinion on the obligations of states in respect of climate change, read out by the President of the Court, Judge Iwasawa Yuji, on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN official reiterates call for Gaza ceasefire as ‚Äònightmare of historic proportions‚Äô unfolds
entry.summary: A senior UN official on Wednesday urged the Security Council to push for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and the release of all hostages, warning that the war has become ‚Äúa nightmare of historic proportions‚Äù and it is ‚Äúlong past time‚Äù for the fighting to end and for hostages to return home.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòCatastrophic birth outcomes‚Äô in Gaza threaten a whole generation, warns UN agency
entry.summary: Pregnant women and newborns in Gaza face ‚Äúcatastrophic‚Äù conditions, including a dysfunctional healthcare system, psychological stress and food deprivation the UN reproductive health agency (UNFPA) reported on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Debate on the situation in the Middle East
entry.summary: The Security Council meets today for its quarterly open debate on the situation in the Middle East, with a focus on the worsening crisis in Gaza. UN Assistant Secretary-General Khaled Khiari is expected to brief on the situation in the war-ravaged enclave where food entry and distribution remain severely restricted, malnutrition is rising, and fuel and shelter supplies are critically scarce. UN News, in coordination with UN Meetings Coverage, brings you live updates from today‚Äôs discussions. UN News App users can follow here.

entry.summary: For the Associated Press, Kimberly Kindy and Amanda Seitz report: The database will‚Ä¶ Tags: ice, Medicaid, privacy

entry.title: Unboxing an antimonial cup
entry.summary: It‚Äôs so toxic, curators can‚Äôt handle it without gloves ‚Äì but drinking wine from this cup was once a popular wellness trend - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: Who was King Tut, the teen pharaoh who captivated the world?
entry.summary:
King Tut, or Tutankhamun, is one of the most famous rulers who ever lived thanks to the 1922 discovery of the pharaoh‚Äôs tomb in Egypt‚Äôs Valley of the Kings. The find stirred the imaginations of millions who were fascinated by the boy king‚Äôs golden-masked mummy.
But what do we really know about King Tut? Although many details of his reign remain lost to time, historians have spent years trying to piece together the pharaoh‚Äôs life and legacy. Here‚Äôs what they‚Äôve learned‚Äîand the biggest questions that remain.
Born during ancient Egypt‚Äôs 18th Dynasty‚Äîwhich stretched from 1550 B.C. to 1295 B.C.‚ÄîTut began his life under a different name: Tutankhaten.
In the years before Tut rose to the throne, Egypt was going through a period of great upheaval. King Amenhotep IV, who is believed‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 of the best European national parks to discover this summer
entry.summary:
Mother Nature was at her most adventurous when she shaped mainland France‚Äôs second-largest national park, the Massif des Ecrins. Fierce summer temperatures can make much of Southern Europe difficult for active, nature-loving breaks in summer. But that still leaves a dazzling array of national parks to explore in the Alps and the north. Here are eight of the best to consider for your next adventure.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Europe‚Äôs national parks contain a magnificent array of landscapes; think glaciers, volcanoes, primeval forests, mountain ranges and wild Atlantic coasts. In many cases, summer is the best time to visit them. Here we‚Äôve picked out eight that show off the continent‚Äôs diversity as well as its beauty.
These parks ar‚Ä¶

entry.title: Diet soda might be making you hungrier
entry.summary:
Artificial sweeteners in diet sodas can potentially trigger brain activity linked to hunger, raising questions about their role in weight control. The idea that diet sodas can help you lose weight is becoming increasingly complicated as emerging research suggests they may confuse the brain‚Äîand trigger an urge to eat.
Millions of people reach for diet sodas each day to reduce sugar intake, manage their weight, or make healthier choices. But new research suggests these artificially sweetened drinks may do more than satisfy a sweet tooth‚Äîthey may also be quietly rewiring how the brain regulates hunger.
Artificial sweeteners have long been controversial for their possible link to cancer and poor gut health. Yet some studies suggest that sweeteners like sucralose may stimulate the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How the province of Girona became one of Spain's gastronomy stars
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
High on a Catalan hilltop just beyond the city of Girona‚Äôs medieval old town, the ma√Ætre d‚Äô at the Roca brothers‚Äô newly opened restaurant, Esperit Roca, draws back a heavy curtain and ushers me into a cavernous, domed wine cellar.
There‚Äôs a sense of theatre as the haunting aria from Handel‚Äôs The Triumph of Time and Truth oratorio announces my arrival and I‚Äôm guided past a city‚Äôs worth of wine racks into a high-ceilinged, industrial-chic dining room that‚Äôs been stylishly converted from a 19th-century fortress.
Esperit Roca is the latest restaurant from chef Joan Roca and his brothers, sommelier Josep and pastry chef Jordi, whose three Michelin-starred El Celler de Can Roca has twice been awarded the number one ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The sirens in ancient mythology weren‚Äôt the seductresses of today
entry.summary:
Sirens torment Ulysses with their enchanting song in Herbert James Draper's 1909 painting titled 'Ulysses and the Sirens.' Draper portrays the Sirens as sexualized mermaids, consistent with other Edwardian era depictions of the creatures. For thousands of years sirens have lured sailors, haunted coastlines‚Äîand shapeshifted through myth and media. Here's how they evolved to the seductive mermaids of our modern imagination.
The Greek hero Odysseus famously faces many travails as he attempts to return home following the Trojan War, from giant cannibals to enigmatic enchantresses. But one challenge stands out as perhaps the most evocative, dangerous, and enduring of them all: the sirens, with their hypnotic and mesmerizing song, who call to passing sailors. To stop is certain death.¬† ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What causes Parkinson's disease? Scientists uncover a new clue.
entry.summary:
A computer illustration of human pegivirus, an RNA (ribonucleic acid) virus scientists believe may be linked to Parkinson's disease. A recent study linking human pegivirus to Parkinson‚Äôs is leading scientists to examine the connection between other viral infections and neurodegenerative diseases.
More than¬†10 million people worldwide¬†are living with Parkinson‚Äôs disease, a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that leads to¬†symptoms such as tremors, slow movement, limb stiffness, and balance issues. Scientists still don‚Äôt know what causes the disease, but it‚Äôs thought to develop due to a complex mixture of genetic and environmental factors, and treatment is still quite limited.¬†
But new research is putting scientists one step closer to some possible answers.¬†

entry.title: 4,000-year-old victim was shot in the back‚Äîand survived
entry.summary:
Close-up of the flint arrowhead embedded in a human rib, found at the Roc de les Orenetes site (Queralbs, Ripoll√®s). This rib bone discovered in a cave in the Spanish Pyrenees tells a story of Bronze Age violence. But who fired the shot?
A flint arrowhead lodged in a rib from a person who lived in the Spanish Pyrenees more than 4,000 years ago was most likely shot during a skirmish with a rival clan, researchers say.
"It is direct evidence of a violent conflict episode," says Carlos Tornero, who led the team that unearthed the rib in a mountain cave 6,000 feet above sea level near the Spanish-French border. His team announced the finding July 8.
Previous excavations at the cave‚Äîcalled Roc de les Orenetes, or "Rock of the Swallows" in Catalan‚Äîunearthed thousands of human b‚Ä¶

entry.title: Need a burnout break? Consider an all-inclusive resort.
entry.summary:
The all-inclusive concept has expanded and evolved to appeal to a wider demographic. Originally designed as a budget-friendly escape, the concept of the all-inclusive resort is gaining in popularity again as exhausted travelers look to indulge in the luxury of doing nothing.
A bucket of beers perspire next to my lounge chair. Turquoise water laps at the shore. A book I haven‚Äôt had time to finish in six months is spread across my lap.¬† Coconut shrimp are on the horizon, to be delivered any minute. Why had I resisted an all-inclusive getaway for so long?¬†
Like many others, I‚Äôve long thought of all-inclusive resorts as a cop-out approach to traveling, characterized by overcrowding and a party-centric, cookie-cutter feel. But reaching a state of total burnout in both life and trav‚Ä¶

entry.title: Dig into Britain‚Äôs ancient past at these 7 archaeological sites
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Despite their ancient age, the UK's most famous archaeological treasures keep revealing new secrets, from recently unearthed dinosaur species to new Roman excavations. To help you follow the archaeology buzz, we dig into the nation‚Äôs top spots to explore our ancient past, where revamped museums, interactive exhibits and hands-on excavation experiences bring our early history vividly to life.
First unearthed in 1939, with the shadow of the Second World War looming, Sutton Hoo is an early medieval royal burial site that‚Äôs famously home to the ship burial of seventh-century Anglo-Saxon King R√¶dwald.

entry.summary: The Security Council on Tuesday adopted a resolution urging all Member States to ‚Äúutilize effectively‚Äù the mechanisms for pacific settlement of disputes as outlined in the United Nations Charter, including ‚Äúnegotiation, enquiry, mediation, conciliation, arbitration, judicial settlement‚Äù and other peaceful means of their choice.

entry.title: Sudan: UN scales up response plan as humanitarian needs rise in Tawila
entry.summary: As the humanitarian crisis deepens in Sudan, the UN and partners have revised and scaled up a response plan to support more than 380,000 displaced people in Tawila, North Darfur state.

entry.title: UN laments US withdrawal from educational and cultural agency
entry.summary: The United States announced on Tuesday that it will leave the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), which will take effect at the end of December 2026.

entry.summary: Protecting underwater ecosystems from the growing interest in rare mineral mining, framing deep-sea laws and building a biobank are among landmark achievements of the UN‚Äôs International Seabed Authority (ISA), which is marking its 30th anniversary at its Kingston, Jamaica, headquarters.

entry.summary: The UN Security Council meets today for a high-level open debate on Promoting International Peace and Security through Multilateralism and Peaceful Settlement of Disputes, chaired by Pakistan‚Äôs Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Mohammad Ishaq Dar. UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres is expected to brief as over 80 Member States join discussions on strengthening diplomacy and mechanisms for conflict prevention. entry.summary: South Sudan‚Äôs dramatic hunger crisis is worsening and millions of people there could miss out on food aid because of the global humanitarian funding crisis, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Fighting for Accountability and Press Freedom in West Africa
entry.summary: For almost 30 years, the Media Foundation for West Africa has supported watchdog journalism and press freedom in both democratic and authoritarian states across the region.

entry.title: What is lightning?
entry.summary:
Lightning flashes during a tropical storm in Guatemala. Here‚Äôs everything you need to know about lightning, from how it forms to common myths and how to stay safe.
Lightning flashing across a darkened sky makes an unforgettable image. With their drama and power, it‚Äôs no wonder people have infused them with symbolic meaning. They‚Äôre associated with mythological deities, such as Zeus and Thor, and even an emoji, in popular culture.
In daily life, these electric currents can be dangerous, sparking intense forest fires and causing deaths. It doesn‚Äôt help that there are many myths about lightning behavior.
From its causes to safety tips, here‚Äôs everything you need to know about these bolts from the blue.

entry.title: This summer has seen the shortest days in Earth‚Äôs recorded history
The race to save the first color photos
entry.summary:
First digitized in 2008 (left), this 1937 photo of a dance performance in Mississippi was created using Dufaycolor, an early color-film product. By 2023, it had been transformed by a form of chemical deterioration known as vinegar syndrome. The revolutionary invention of autochromes changed photography. As those pictures decay, they're revealing a new kind of beauty.
In the early 1980s,¬†the late National Geographic Society photographer turned archivist Volkmar Wentzel was delving through storage when he stumbled onto something both breathtaking and heartbreaking: a box of delicate glass panels, most of them the size of postcards, displaying color images captured in the early 20th century. Many were deteriorating, their once crisp scenes speckled with ghostly snowflakes, obscured by‚Ä¶

entry.title: Plan a day in Switzerland's underrated financial capital
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Switzerland‚Äôs largest city, straddling the Limmat River and facing the pristine shores of Lake Zurich, has long been best known for its financial clout and Swiss efficiency. But these days its cultural scene is also booming, with everything from ‚Äòblackout‚Äô dining concepts to fashion co-ops set beneath railway arches. Here‚Äôs how best to take in the city in just 14 hours.
The combination of the lake‚Äôs glassy water and this swimming club has made such an impression on locals that it‚Äôs kept them rising at dawn for more than 130 years. The Seebad‚Äôs two-floor wooden bathhouse debuted in 1890 with curtained changing rooms, ladders directly into the lake and diving boards, and it‚Äôs been eulogised ever since by bathers an‚Ä¶

entry.title: The hunt for the world‚Äôs rarest duck
entry.summary: Known by locals as fotsimaso, or white eye, the Madagascar pochard is a diver. Like other diving ducks‚Äîand unlike dabbling ducks‚Äîtheir legs are farther back on their bodies, which helps propel them underwater and makes them appear more upright than dabblers when standing. They are the only ducks in their genus (Aythya) that live almost entirely on invertebrates, with a particular fondness for mothlike caddis flies that breed in the vegetation surrounding lakes. In flight, the critically endangered birds reveal pale bellies and white underwings. The dogged search for a bird that many people figured had gone extinct included torrential rains, washed-out bridges, swine flu, and unrelenting obsession. The Madagascar pochard, compared with other ducks, has little to c‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Sicilian town feeds the world‚Äôs almond craze
The most expensive mistake in ancient Roman history
entry.summary:
The passage is easy to miss.¬†A paragraph-long anecdote in the¬†Annals¬†by the Roman historian Tacitus, it tells a story found nowhere else, about an unpopular legate forcing legionaries into a treacherous mine at the frontier of the empire. It takes place during the reign of Claudius (A.D. 41‚Äì54), a time of furious expansion when Rome sought to swallow up the borderlands and their resources. The location mentioned in the Tacitus passage is vague, described as ‚Äúin the district of Mattium,‚Äù just outside of Roman-occupied Germania Superior. But the goal is clear: to find more of a metal that powered the realm.
Silver trickled down from patricians, officers, and soldiers to the rest of the economy, in the form of coins and ingots and jewelry. Coins were not merely currency. Stamped with the‚Ä¶

entry.title: Spain‚Äôs most decadent foodie town isn‚Äôt where you think it is
entry.summary:
People from around the world are traveling to Astorga for its burgeoning food scene. For hikers and walkers, the Spanish city is a lesser-known stop along the famous Camino de Santiago (Saint James Way). Located in the interior of Iberia, this scenic city has mastered the art of savory and sweet with its iconic regional cuisine and centuries-old chocolate industry.
From A Coru√±a to Valencia, the Spanish coastline is rife with cities that have earned worldwide acclaim for their food scenes. However, those who venture into the country‚Äôs interior can find a truly rewarding destination‚ÄîAstorga. A prominent settlement within the autonomous community of Castilla y Le√≥n, this scenic city has mastered the art of savory and sweet dishes, providing visitors with an opportunity to sample suga‚Ä¶

entry.title: Doha agreement brings DR Congo government and M23 rebels a step closer to peace
entry.summary: An agreement signed by the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and the Congo River Alliance/March 23 Movement (AFC/M23) has been hailed by the UN peacekeeping mission in the country (MONUSCO) as ‚Äúan important step towards sustainable peace.‚Äù

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: A practical guide to long-distance walking in the UK
entry.summary:
There are now 16 official National Trails extending across the length and breadth of England and Wales. There is tremendous fun to be had striding across dale and over fell, up mountain gradient and along the precipice of a wildflower-capped sea cliff, but with so many designated walks to choose from, what should you know before setting off?
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Long-distance rambling in Britain is part of¬†a¬†correspondingly long tradition. In fact, few nationalities enjoy it quite as much as the British: from the South West Coast Path at Land‚Äôs End in Cornwall, to the Cape Wrath Trail in the Scottish Highlands, you'll always find a Brit in an anorak. In 1965, the Pennine Way became the first of the UK's National Trails, and now ‚Äî 6‚Ä¶

entry.title: Desks become beds as Haitian school shelters people displaced by violence
entry.summary: Gang violence in Haiti has displaced hundreds of thousands of people and many are finding shelter in former schools where belief in the power of education remains strong.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: This hidden Italian town is perfect for a summer escape
entry.summary:
Evade the summer holiday crowds along Italy's most popular coastlines and head to Basilicata instead. Known as the ‚ÄòPearl of the Tyrrhenian‚Äô, this little-known stretch of Basilicata goes all out on natural beauty and southern Italian charm. Here's how to spend a leisurely weekend in Maratea.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Imagine if the Amalfi Coast was all but unknown ‚Äî that‚Äôs the charm of Maratea. Bordered by Campania to the north and Calabria to the south, the municipality occupies the only portion of the Tyrrhenian coast in the whole of Basilicata. It‚Äôs a near 20-mile stretch home to striking black-sand beaches, boat-fresh seafood and panoramic vistas overlooking the glittering Gulf of Policastro. But despite possessing all the hallmarks‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who was Nelson Mandela?
entry.summary:
Former South African president and civil rights advocate Nelson Mandela dedicated his life to fighting for equality‚Äîand ultimately helped topple South Africa's racist system of apartheid. His accomplishments are now celebrated each year on July 18, Nelson Mandela International Day.

This activist dedicated his life to dismantling racism‚Äîand went from being the world‚Äôs most famous political prisoner to South Africa‚Äôs first Black president. Nelson Mandela was born on July 18, 1918, in what was then known as the Union of South Africa, a dominion of the British Empire. Although the majority of the country‚Äôs inhabitants were Black, they were dominated by a white minority population that controlled the land, the wealth, and the government‚Äîa discriminatory social structure tha‚Ä¶

entry.title: My best summers were spent at Grand Canyon Lodge‚Äînow it‚Äôs gone
entry.summary:
I‚Äôm not usually one to get weepy over a hotel, let alone a patio and some rough-hewn wooden furniture. But when Arizona‚Äôs famous Grand Canyon Lodge and a number of smaller adjacent structures burned down on the night of July 12 in the Dragon Bravo Fire, a blaze that to date has consumed 11,344 acres and remains entirely uncontained, it left a hole in more than just the conifer forest of the North Rim. My heart, my friends‚Äô hearts‚Äîthere‚Äôs a hole in each of these now. And there are similar holes in the hearts of thousands of folks across the globe who also loved, and still love, and will forever love, that rustic palace, that gobsmacking view, that superlative place.
In 2024, close to five million visitors experienced the beauty and wonder of Grand Canyon National Park, but only ten per‚Ä¶

entry.title: See 100 years of New York City
entry.summary:
In the summer of 1957, a replica of the Mayflower sailed into New York Harbor. Dubbed the Mayflower II, it had just finished retracing the Pilgrims‚Äô 1620 journey across the Atlantic to establish a colony in America. New York City celebrated its arrival with a ticker-tape parade.
That November, National Geographic published an article written by the ship‚Äôs captain about the Mayflower II‚Äôs voyage, full of photos of its ocean journey and a victorious arrival in New York City (which was not a stop on the original ship‚Äôs route to Plymouth, Massachusetts).
As the city this year celebrates the 400th anniversary of its founding as the Dutch outpost New Amsterdam, National Geographic looked back on its coverage of the city over the last century.
An early article highlighted its draws‚Ä¶

entry.title: Felix Baumgartner, famed pilot and BASE jumper, dies at 56
entry.summary:
Felix Baumgartner, the world-renowned Austrian pilot who was named National Geographic‚Äôs 2013¬†People‚Äôs Choice Adventurer of the Year¬†for his fearless aerial feats, has died in Italy.¬†
According to local media¬†reports, the pilot died after crashing into a hotel pool while paragliding on the Adriatic coast, injuring another person in the accident.
National Geographic has reached out to Baumgartner‚Äôs representatives.
According to the Associated Press, the city‚Äôs mayor confirmed Baumgartner‚Äôs death in a social media post.
‚ÄúOur community is deeply affected by the tragic disappearance of Felix Baumgartner, a figure of global prominence, a symbol of courage and passion for extreme flight,‚Äù Mayor Massimiliano Ciarpella said.¬†
Baumgartner leaves behind a soaring legacy, set‚Ä¶

entry.title: This underdiagnosed vein disorder affects 4 in 10 Americans
entry.summary:
A nurse practitioner examines a patient with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), a vascular condition in which damaged leg veins impair blood flow back to the heart. CVI can lead to symptoms such as swelling, skin changes, and venous ulcers if left untreated. From tingly legs to bulging veins, these warning signs may point to chronic venous insufficiency‚Äîa widespread circulatory issue doctors say is on the rise.
Swelling, aching calves, tingling, or bulging veins might seem like everyday discomforts, but they could point to a hidden problem in your circulatory system. A surprisingly common yet underrecognized condition called chronic venous insufficiency is behind a growing number of cases‚Äîand scientists say it‚Äôs far more widespread than most people realize.
Here are five thin‚Ä¶

entry.title: Wellness is going high tech at these hotels
entry.summary:
In addition to massages and facials, hotel spas are adding in space-age wellness treatments to their services. All-natural treatments like aromatherapy and mud facials used to be all the rage. But now, top hotels around the world are offering something decidedly different.
Natural treatments and products have long been wellness buzzwords‚Äîthink of aromatherapy sessions using plant-derived ingredients, or skin-smoothing immersions in mineral-rich volcanic mud. But now, a different approach is on the rise.
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs becoming more common is a model where everything is scientifically calibrated,‚Äù says Amy Larocca, author of the recent book How to Be Well: Navigating Our Self-Care Epidemic, One Dubious Cure at a Time, a skeptic‚Äôs take on wellness culture in the United States.
On ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What do you do with thousands of dead Everglades pythons?
entry.summary: Just after midnight, Elle Barbeito drove her Dodge pickup deep into the shadows of the Florida Everglades. After hours navigating narrow marsh roads, past towering bald cypresses and raucous shoots of bromeliads, she suddenly pulled onto the shoulder and aimed a flashlight at a writhing patch of prehistoric-looking ferns. ‚ÄúPython!‚Äù Barbeito shouted, pointing to a metallic sheen of scales glistening like silken chain mail in the moonlight. The next part would require her gun.¬† https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2507-Python-Fashion-Map/builds/main/html/_graphic.html No one can say for certain how Burmese pythons arrived in the Everglades in the first place or how many there are today, though conservative estimates put their population in the tens of thousands. What we‚Ä¶

entry.title: As war rages on in Ukraine, organised crime is taking new forms
entry.summary: Almost four years after Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion, criminal groups in Ukraine are adapting their business models amid displacement, rising trafficking risks and an increased demand for synthetic drugs, the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) said in a report published on Friday.

entry.title: The best place to snorkle with whale sharks? It's in Australia
entry.summary:
Whale sharks, humpbacks, southern right whales, orcas, mighty mantas, turtles and some 700 species of fish await just offshore, often within paddling distance of the beach‚Äôs windblown dunes. Whale sharks, coral reefs and safari tents amid the dunes: this remote lodge immerses travellers in Western Australia‚Äôs astounding marine world.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Ningaloo Coast is where outback, reef and ranges meet. Here, on the northwestern fringes of Australia, 745 miles above Perth on a rocky thumb of a promontory that juts into the Indian Ocean, great ochre canyons and stretches of flat, red earth slip into water that‚Äôs as bright blue as a kingfisher. This is also where marine giants meet ‚Äî among them whale sharks, humpbacks, south‚Ä¶
